The point is that all three periodic functions \(f_1(t)\), \(f_2(t)\), \(f_3(t)\) will give rise to a different Fourier series but all will represent the function \(f(t) = t^2\) over \(0 < t < \pi\). Fourier series obtained by extending functions in this sort of way are often referred to as half-range series.

Normally, in applications, we require either a Fourier Cosine series (so we would complete a definition as in (a) above to obtain an even periodic function) or a Fourier Sine series (for which, as in (b) above, we need an odd periodic function.)

The above considerations apply equally well for a function defined over any interval.

Example

Obtain the half range Fourier Sine series to represent \(f(t) = t^2\), \(0 < t < 3\).

Solution

We first extend \(f(t)\) as an odd periodic function \(F(t)\) of period 6: \(f(t) = -t^2\), \(-3 < t < 0\). So \[ F(t) = \begin{cases} -t^2 \hspace{1cm} -3 < t < 0 \\ t^2 \hspace{1.4cm} 0 < t < 3 \end{cases} \]


We now evaluate the Fourier series of \(F(t)\) by standard techniques but take advantage of the symmetry and put \(a_n = 0\), \(n = 0, 1, 2, \dots \).

Using the results for the Fourier Sine coefficients for period \(T\) as \[ b_n = \dfrac{2}{T} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\frac{T}{2}} ^{\frac{T}{2}} } F(t) \sin \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t}{T} \right) dt ,\] we put \(T = 6\) and, since the integrand is even (a product of 2 odd functions), we can write \[ b_n = \dfrac{2}{3} \displaystyle{ \int _{0} ^{3} } F(t) \sin \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t}{6} \right) dt = \dfrac{2}{3} \displaystyle{ \int _{0} ^{3} } t^2 \sin \left( \dfrac{n \pi t}{3} \right) dt \] (Note that we always integrate over the originally defined range, in this case \(0 < t < 3\).)

We now have to integrate by parts (twice!) \[ \begin{align} b_n &= \dfrac{2}{3} \left\{ \left[ -\dfrac{3t^2}{n\pi} \cos \left( \dfrac{n\pi t}{3} \right) \right] _0 ^3 + 2\left( \dfrac{3}{n\pi} \right) \int _0 ^3 t \cos \left( \dfrac{n \pi t}{3} \right) dt \right\} \\ &= \dfrac{2}{3} \left\{ -\dfrac{27}{n \pi} \cos n\pi + \dfrac{6}{n\pi} \left[ \dfrac{3}{n\pi} t \sin \left( \dfrac{n \pi t}{3} \right) \right] _0^3 - \left( \dfrac{6}{n\pi} \right) \left( \dfrac{3}{n\pi} \right) \int _0^3 \sin \left( \dfrac{n \pi t}{3} \right) dt \right\} \\ &= \dfrac{2}{3} \left\{ -\dfrac{27}{n \pi} \cos n\pi -\dfrac{18}{n^2\pi^2} \left[ -\dfrac{3}{n\pi}\cos \left( \dfrac{n\pi t}{3} \right) \right] _0^3 \right\} \\ &= \dfrac{2}{3} \left\{ - \dfrac{27}{n\pi} \cos n\pi + \dfrac{54}{n^3\pi^3} \left( \cos n\pi -1 \right) \right\} \end{align} \] so

\( b_n = \begin{cases} -\dfrac{18}{n\pi} \hspace{2.4cm} n = 2, 4, 6, \dots \\ \dfrac{18}{n\pi} - \dfrac{72}{n^3\pi^3} \hspace{1cm} n = 1, 3, 5 \dots \end{cases} \)

So the required Fourier series is \[ F(t) = 18 \left( \dfrac{1}{\pi} - \dfrac{4}{\pi^3} \right) \sin \left( \dfrac{\pi t}{3} \right) - \dfrac{18}{2\pi}\sin \left( \dfrac{2\pi t}{3} \right) + 18 \left( \dfrac{1}{3\pi} - \dfrac{4}{27\pi^3} \right) \sin (\pi t) - \dots \]
